artist: Artist: Peter de Jode; Artist: After Maarten de Vos
creditline: Gift of funds from Barbara S. Longfellow
description: couple with standing man at left, offering jewelry to a seated woman looking down at her bare breast; woman leans her PL elbow on a box with broken pots inside; more broken pots in LRC; winter landscape in background with bare trees and ruined buildings; text at bottom below image
inscription:
Inscription and Stamp

along top edge, in the print: [MELANCHOLICVS]; URC, in the print: [4]; along bottom edge, printed: [Martino Vossio inuentore  Petro Jodoeo coelatore  Crispianus Passoe, imprimit.]
markings: on back, LLC, stamped in black: monogram
provenance: Possibly Gaston de Ramaix (Belgium, 1878-1937, see Lugt 4099). Probably Henri Godts, Brussels, March 14, 2014, lot 46; [Nicolaas Teeuwisse, Berlin, cat. XV, p. 18-21, no. 6, illus.]
text:
A miser and a woman seemingly depressed over failed alchemical experiments embody melancholy, the personality trait of sadness, the darkness brought on by an excess of black bile. Just as the woman could not achieve happiness by trying to change lead into gold, the treasures of the earth—jewels and gold—will not lift her spirits.

This plate belongs to a series of four engravings designed by Maarten de Vos, the most important painter in late 16th-century Antwerp, and executed by the highly skilled Flemish engraver Pieter d Jode I.
title: Melancholic
